I'd say a bulk of Labour advocates for at the very least a market economy socialist state. 

And since politics is a spectrum, I would say British politics has been dabbling with fascism for a while, with recent Tory Governments shuffling closer and closer.

Labour are factually not Marxist right now, unless they were espousing socialism as a manifesto policy, which they are likely not.

​

Take a look at Umberto Eco's defining characteristics of fascism. 

**1. The cult of tradition.** ‚ÄúOne has only to look at the syllabus of every fascist movement to find the major traditionalist thinkers. The Nazi gnosis was nourished by traditionalist, syncretistic, occult elements.‚Äù

2. The rejection of modernism. ‚ÄúThe Enlightenment, the Age of Reason, is seen as the beginning of modern depravity. In this sense Ur-Fascism can be defined as irrationalism.‚Äù

**3. The cult of action for action‚Äôs sake.** ‚ÄúAction being beautiful in itself, it must be taken before, or without, any previous reflection. Thinking is a form of emasculation.‚Äù

4. Disagreement is treason. ‚ÄúThe critical spirit makes distinctions, and to distinguish is a sign of modernism. In modern culture the scientific community praises disagreement as a way to improve knowledge.‚Äù

5. Fear of difference. ‚ÄúThe first appeal of a fascist or prematurely fascist movement is an appeal against the intruders. Thus Ur-Fascism is racist by definition.‚Äù

**6. Appeal to social frustration.** ‚ÄúOne of the most typical features of the historical fascism was the appeal to a frustrated middle class, a class suffering from an economic crisis or feelings of political humiliation, and frightened by the pressure of lower social groups.‚Äù

**7. The obsession with a plot.** ‚ÄúThe followers must feel besieged. The easiest way to solve the plot is the appeal to xenophobia.‚Äù

8. The humiliation by the wealth and force of their enemies. ‚ÄúBy a continuous shifting of rhetorical focus, the enemies are at the same time too strong and too weak.‚Äù

9. Pacifism is trafficking with the enemy. ‚ÄúFor Ur-Fascism there is no struggle for life but, rather, life is lived for struggle.‚Äù

10. Contempt for the weak. ‚ÄúElitism is a typical aspect of any reactionary ideology.‚Äù

11. Everybody is educated to become a hero. ‚ÄúIn Ur-Fascist ideology, heroism is the norm. This cult of heroism is strictly linked with the cult of death.‚Äù

12. Machismo and weaponry. ‚ÄúMachismo implies both disdain for women and intolerance and condemnation of nonstandard sexual habits, from chastity to homosexuality.‚Äù

**13. Selective populism.** ‚ÄúThere is in our future a TV or Internet populism, in which the emotional response of a selected group of citizens can be presented and accepted as the Voice of the People.‚Äù

14. Ur-Fascism speaks Newspeak. ‚ÄúAll the Nazi or Fascist schoolbooks made use of an impoverished vocabulary, and an elementary syntax, in order to limit the instruments for complex and critical reasoning.‚Äù

​

I've bolded the points I think we are on the brink of.

Lets start with the unlawful prorogation of Parliament.  It shows his clear disregard for playing by the rules, and allowing Parliamentary sovereignty. This actually led to a cross party "Church House declaration" where over 160 MPs pledged to congregate an alternative Parliament if Johnson prorogued it.

Then examine who he's stacking his Cabinet with. Priti Patel is infamous for her secret meetings with Israeli officials, and the Attorney General Braverman believes in a war against "Cultural Marxists".
You make a very good point, to be honest
Exactly. Its unsettling to think people are basing everything off of  cheap lie.
I think people don't know what socialism, and capitalism mean, or what libertarianism and authoritarianism mean. And thats where the break in critical thinking is.
I think Starmer will be the Kinnock of the 2020s, hopefully he makes space for a more Nandy-type leader than a Blair-type leader, however.

I think it is abundantly clear the economy needs to be fully reexamined and fully recreated.

I do agree that Johnson seems to be making some moderate plays in order to broaden his appeal, however his Government has been making some vaguely authoritarian moves.

Him doing the same as Corbyn is better for the Labour party, though.

Corbyn was so tainted and so divisive he could not make any right moves, even if when Starmer does it, its "more right".

I love Corbyn, and admire the fuck out of the man, but unfortunately this country has succumbed to the fake reality the media has created.
Sure, but you do see it brought up a lot, and I think people have a very warped sense of history.

There's something missing from this crisis to be honest. People keep harking back to the "Blitz spirit", but for every act of solidarity, all I see is more division and more hypocrisy.

If you want to protect the NHS, you would logically also want to see it well managed and funded? So why would you clap for the NHS and post it of Facebook when you've voted Tory for the last decade? 

Or those people who bullied that NHS nurse at ALDI. Or the celebrities spreading the 5G rumours. How has so much of our nation seemingly just lost their grip on rationality and why has 2020 been so surreal?
The Government should have requisitioned it.
Why would anyone think it is politically savvy to not distance yourself from one of the most divisive politicians of a lifetime?

Exactly. Maduro is SINO - he hasn't attempted to actually remove capitalism and Chavista "socialism" made no developments towards any national industry.

Socialism of the 21st Century is 50% myth and corruption and 50% social democracy.

We're in a crisis. The Government is popular right now. It would be day-one suicide for Starmer to disagree with popular policy.

Here, he looks like he's co-operative.

I sincerely hope Starmer explores federalism in greater depth than his predecessors. It might also help Labour work towards solving its massive failures in Scotland by giving them essentially Devomax, but for other regions like Cornwall, Wales and NI.
